blocks.text:
From equations (1) and (2) we have:

\[ p_n = 510 - 0.0035h \] 

and substituting for $p_n$ in (3), we get:

\[ \frac{dp}{dh} = -0.0035 \] 

Separating the variables gives:

\[ \int dp = -0.0035 \int dh \] 

Integrating, the limits to be taken are $p_0$ and $p_n$, and those to $h$ are $0$ and $h$:

\[ \log(p_n - 286) - \log(p_0 - 286) = -0.0035h \] 

which may be further simplified by substituting for $p_0$ and $C$.

blocks.title: General Linear Equations of the First Order, i.e., equations of the type

blocks.text:
\[ \frac{dy}{dx} + ay = b \] 

where $a$ and $b$ can either be constants or functions.

The solution of this equation may be written as

\[ y = e^{-\int a \, dx} \left( \int b e^{\int a \, dx} \, dx + C \right) \] 

The proof of this result depends on the rule for differentiating a product, viz., \( u \frac{dv}{dx} + v \frac{du}{dx} \); the reasoning being as follows:

Let us consider the simplest case in which the equation becomes
